data.title: Some keys are not recognized correctly when using a Japanese keyboard
data.body:
Keybindings for certain keys do not work as intended with a Japanese keyboard on macOS. When defining keybindings, the @ key (right of 'P') and '[' key are both recognized as a [. Shift+@ is recognized as shift+`. The ¥ key is 'unrecognized' and shift+¥ is recognized as shift+\.

There may be issues with other keys, too. I noticed this one specifically because there is no ` key on a Japanese keyboard and it's used to open the terminal. 

I'm using my MacBook's default keyboard which is Japanese. I also have a bluetooth Apple Japanese keyboard that experiences the same issue.

- VSCode Version: 1.10.1
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open 'Preferences -> Keyboard Shortcuts' (cmd+k cmd+s)
2. Click 'Define Keybinding' (cmd+k cmd+k)
3. Press @ or ¥ on a Japanese keyboard.

Here's a picture of the keyboard layout for reference:
![mla22j](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1572318/24593427/4a7be108-185e-11e7-8c53-b04922b6c234.jpg)

data.title: Fixes #1623 and #20953
data.body:
Issues #1623 and #20953 had root causes in the emmet library.
The fix was made in the emmet library and cherry-picked to our custom emmet library
https://github.com/ramya-rao-a/emmet/commit/b4d3edc30de7fa98032302cd1f017a940ab879fd and https://github.com/ramya-rao-a/emmet/commit/4fce82e3a49aabaa7a666b3d6308f1cfbd40018d

This PR is to update the commit hash for emmet, so that fix is available in VS Code as well

data.title: How do I enable extensions in the extensions dir in OSS Dev mode
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->
master/
```
commit 6f42a236d521e9016a4d4fbf6aaf33cf3d9fad4e
Merge: 01d1e95 07ca248
Author: Daniel Imms <tyriar@tyriar.com>
Date:   Fri Mar 31 23:25:07 2017 -0700

    Merge pull request #23784 from DickvdBrink/patch-1

    Fixed typo in terminal.contribution description
```
Ubuntu 16.04

I'm trying to patch something in the vscode codebase, 
I require the php extension to work in order for me to test my changes.
How do I enable all the extensions that ship with code in my config?

This is the config I'm using (just added runtime args to the original Launch Vs Code config)

```
		{
			"type": "chrome",
			"request": "launch",
			"name": "Launch VS Code",
			"windows": {
				"runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/scripts/code.bat"
			},
			"osx": {
				"runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/scripts/code.sh"
			},
			"linux": {
				"runtimeExecutable": "${workspaceRoot}/scripts/code.sh",
				"runtimeArgs": [
					"--extensions-dir", "${workspaceRoot}/extensions/"
				]
			},
			"urlFilter": "*index.html*"
		}
```

This does seem to cause the extension viewlet to list all the packages in the extension dir. But I still get this error when I launch my this config (Listen for Xdebug):

```
  "version": "0.2.0",
  // "debugServer": 4711, // Uncomment for debugging the adapter
  "configurations": [
    {
      "name": "Listen for XDebug",
      "type": "php",
      "request": "launch",
      "port": 9000,
      "log": true
    },
    {
      "name": "Launch",
      "request": "launch",
      "type": "php",
      "program": "${file}",
      "cwd": "${workspaceRoot}",
      "externalConsole": false
    }
  ]
}
```

error:
`Configured debug type 'php' is not supported.`

data.title: Intellisense not using JSDoc for imported files
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.0-insider (32942fd950)
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a file called `test.ts` with the following contents:

```
/** This is my test */
export function test() {

}
```

2. Create a file called `test2.ts` with the following content:

```
import { test } from './test';
```

Intellisense within `test.ts` works correctly:

![working](http://i.imgur.com/wYwtZe9.png)

Intellisense within `test2.ts` doesn't work correctly:

![not working](http://i.imgur.com/O8R0Ss0.png)

But it shows up after you autocomplete:

![sorta working](http://i.imgur.com/gGcdH0R.png)

It doesn't seem to be a TypeScript issue as it also occurs with `.js` files.

data.title: built-in TypeScript Format not working for minified files
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  we have a very large auto-generated javascript library that needs to be uncompressed/beautified. loading it in vscode, the first "line" is over 300,000 characters.   After attempting to use "Format Document",  the code looks as follows:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7736675/24591381/ea8da06e-17cd-11e7-9045-59793b0cfaf1.png)

2.  using npm install js-beautify version 1.6.12  we get:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7736675/24591392/33729d8e-17ce-11e7-9bec-931532f0a3f5.png)

3.  this is similar to what we get using the beautify function in notepad++

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7736675/24591399/4d27c9de-17ce-11e7-9c0e-d7abe66eae08.png)

4.  due to the huge size of this library and its connection to an internal program,  I can't really post it for validation.   In notepad++,  this file is 55,000 lines long after decompression.

I see no settings that would impact this, and am wondering if it is purely an issue of having js-beautify updated in vscode, if that is what you use. 

let me know if there is something else I can do to help

data.title: Git: Show original image side by side with changed image.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Add an image to git
2. Commit
3. Change the image
4. Select the changed image in the list of git detected changes
5. The git module will fail to compare with the old image stating that it can't compare binary files.

It would be nice that, instead of failing, it shows image side by side.

data.title: Add noValuePreselect option to showInputBox
data.body:
Allow extensions to decide if a value passed to vscode.window.showInputBox should start selected or not. Defaults to current behavior as to not break the experience of existing extensions.
Fixes https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/10582.

-- Sorry for the English, I used Google Translator --

When using <kbd>Alt</kbd> + <kbd>Z</kbd> (WordWrap on and off) it is not affecting the whole editor any more, just each file.

I'd rather have it affect the entire editor, or at least have one option whether it should affect every publisher or not;

I believe it's about Case #21801.

Maybe 'wordWrapColumn' should be independent of wordwrap. Perhaps the idea was not very clear. Excuse me.

editor.wordwrap: on or off
editor.WordWrapColumn: on or off
(Rename the old configuration to that name or similar)editor.WordWrapColumnValue: 80

- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- Extensions: none
---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Start VS Code
2. Select the **File | New File** menu item
3. Type: `Hello, World!`
4. Select the **File | Save As** menu item
5. Type a few characters to replace the default filename (`Untitled-1`) in the **Save As** field
6. Hit *Cmd+A*, or select **Selection | Select All**

Actual Results:
Nothing happens

Expected Results:
Since the **Save As** field has input focus, that the filename you've typed in that field gets selected.

data.title: Find box: as stupid as it gets
data.body: **The search bar behaviour is completely counter-productive**. First, it does not even auto focus the cursor on itself. Secondly, when re-opening it with a small text selection active, it persists with the previous search instead of taking the highlighted text for the new search query. Last, it seems impossible to change the Shift+F3 shortcut to something more useful like, F4, which I've been using for decades with Crimson Editor.

data.title: How to automatically test a completion item provider?
data.body:
Hi,

is there any way to automatically test completion providers in own extensions? 
The extension I'm writing isn't just a simple word completion provider. It does much more than that replacing part of the text before the position where completion was requested. There are some edge cases which make it hard to test manually every time.
I'd like to write some tests based on specific input and expected outcome. Is it possible to apply a CompletionItem on the editor using API?

Any example extension that has such tests?

data.title: Feature request: collapse parent directory
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 
```
commit f51ed6a63c3bf316822459840705e62bce932783
Author: Sandeep Somavarapu <sasomava@microsoft.com>
Date:   Mon Mar 20 00:46:24 2017 +0100

    #18095 Show kyebinding label if has highlights
```
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 

Sometimes I end up in a vendor/node_modules directory, usually with a very long list of subdirectories,  by jumping around code bases. I'd like to collapse such directory (on the left hand side directory browser view) after finding what I was looking for while also keeping other  more relevant directories open.

I think something like a menu option that says `collapse parent directory` that appears when right clicking on a directory would suffice

![optimised](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8478946/24584640/ea46f358-1741-11e7-835f-3fa927c4146b.gif)

data.title: terminal sendtext blocks if application running in PowerShell
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 v1607

Steps to Reproduce:

1. (If set differently) set `"terminal.integrated.shell.windows"` to `"C:\\WINDOWS\\Sysnative\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\powershell.exe"`
2. Create "Hello World Extension" tutorial as from https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/extensions/example-hello-world
3. Replace `vscode.window.showInformationMessage('Hello World!');` in extension.ts/js with `let term = vscode.window.createTerminal(); term.sendText("telnet"); term.sendText("quit");`
4. Debug extension and execute `Hello World` command

**Expected result**: the telnet client would immediately open in the new terminal and then exit.
**Observed result**: the telnet client remains open with no text. Typing `quit` in the terminal will exit telnet, and then `quit` is immediately sent into the terminal, giving an error stating the command does not exist.

data.title: Terminal confirmOnExit should only warn when the terminal shell is running something

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: We could check if the shell process from node-pty has any child processes using something like `pgrep -P <pid>`. If we do this confirmOnExit=true may be better off as the default.

data.title: Pin files
data.body: when i work in a big project sometimes i can't find the file which i work on mostly , so a feature like 'pin the file' seems will solve this small issue

data.title: Line height and font size are too large by default

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2 - OS Version: win10 x64 My monitor native resolution is 1920x1200
When opening any file in VSCode, it shows only **56 lines** at any time. I feel that the current line height and font size are too much by default. _For reference:_ ``` Sublime Text 3: 71 lines Notepad++ 6.9: 65 lines gVim 7.4: 66 lines UltraEdit 23: 67 lines ``` _In contrast, Atom 1.15 displays even less: 49 lines_
By default VSCode has in its settings: ``` "editor.fontSize": 14, // Controls the font size in pixels. "editor.lineHeight": 0 // Controls the line height. Use 0 to compute the lineHeight from the fontSize. ``` If I set them to **13** and **15** respectively then the visible lines area becomes on par with the other editors: 71 lines.
Also, _(while using the default `Dark+` theme and the default setting ` "editor.fontFamily": "Consolas, 'Courier New', monospace"`)_ with my suggested settings, 13pt Consolas *I think* it is appears a bit boldish. _Changing the value`"editor.fontWeight": "normal"` to anything below 400 doesn't make a difference. (related issue: #381)_ That's why I believe that, in conjunction with the above two suggested changes, it would be even better to switch to a slightly different font that would support setting `fontWeight` below 400 e.g. something like "Consolas Light" -I know that this font currently doesn't exit- )
**So, my suggestion is to change the default values of these settings to 13 and 15 respectively, plus lower the `fontWeight` value somehow** ----- Here is VSCode with its default settings: [screenshot 682](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/723651/24582811/7b7b0e24-1740-11e7-92d0-b488b89e6de9.png) And here is comparison of VSCode with my suggested settings vs Sublime Text 3: [screenshot 678](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/723651/24582818/a8b5cb2c-1740-11e7-95de-ee34554b7b72.png) [screenshot 678b](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/723651/24582821/bfba6350-1740-11e7-8451-9aaec3773127.png)

data.title: [Feature request] Gray out unused or unreachable code in editor
data.body: Feature request here: Gray out unused code (unused `import`'s and `require`'s and unreachable code) in editor with capability to remove it using IntelliSense and <kbd>Ctrl+.</kbd> keyboard shortcut. Primarily needed in Angular 2+ and TypeScript projects.

data.title: Use .gitignore to hide/mark files in the file explorer

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
Forking https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/78 where there is much discussion

Hiding files in the file explorer is currently possible with the `files.exclude` setting.

Would we hide .gitignored files or color/annotate them somehow?

Would we use `git check-ignore`/`git ls-files` or do we need something faster? Would it make sense to use part of ripgrep here?
